title: Digital Services Act
content:
{{Short description|European Union regulation on digital services content}}
{{Infobox EU legislation|number=(EU) 2022/2065|made=19 October 2022|title=Regulation on a Single Market For Digital Services|madeby=[[European Parliament]] and [[Council of the European Union]]|CommProp=COM/2020/825 final|implementation=|status=current|type=regulation|Parties=|madeunder=|EEA=yes|OJrefurl=http://data.europa.eu/eli/reg/2022/2065/oj|OJref=OJ L 277, 27.10.2022, p. 1–102}}
The '''Digital Services Act (DSA)''' is an [[EU regulation]] to modernise the [[Electronic Commerce Directive 2000|e-Commerce Directive]] regarding illegal content, transparent advertising, and disinformation.<ref name="euractive20200808"/><ref name="ft20201028"/>

It was submitted along with the [[Digital Markets Act]] (DMA) by the [[European Commission]] to the [[European Parliament]] and the [[Council of the European Union|Council]] on 15 December 2020.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://ec.europa.eu/digital-single-market/en/digital-services-act-package |title=The Digital Services Act package|publisher=Directorate-General CONNECT of the [[European Commission]]|access-date=December 29, 2020}}</ref><ref name="auto1">{{cite magazine| url= https://app.ft.com/content/22bda533-db74-4a3d-917b-75ac23c0f27f | title= Brussels'plans to tackle digital 'gatekeepers' spark fevered debate |last1= Espinoza |first1=Javier|last2=Hindley|first2=Scott|publisher=[[Financial Times]] | date= December 16, 2019 |access-date=December 29, 2020}}</ref> The DSA was prepared by the [[Executive Vice President of the European Commission for A Europe Fit for the Digital Age]] [[Margrethe Vestager]] and by the [[European Commissioner for Internal Market]] [[Thierry Breton]], as members of the [[Von der Leyen Commission]].<ref>{{Cite news|date=2020-12-15|title=EU Digital Services Act set to bring in new rules for tech giants|language=en-GB|work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-55307115|access-date=2021-01-24}}</ref>

On 22 April 2022, European policymakers reached an agreement on the Digital Services Act.<ref name="Satariano_20220422"/> The European Parliament approved the DSA along with the [[Digital Markets Act]] on 5 July 2022.<ref name="parl072022">{{Cite web|date=2022-07-05|title=Digital Services: landmark rules adopted for a safer, open online environment|access-date=2022-07-05|language=en|url=https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20220701IPR34364/digital-services-landmark-rules-adopted-for-a-safer-open-online-environment}}</ref> On 4 October 2022, the European Council gave its final approval to the Regulation on a Digital Services Act.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=297caa4e-686c-452c-a527-c56fb3fba7ee | title=The EU Digital Services Act - Europe's New Regime for Content Moderation | date=4 October 2022 }}</ref> It was published in the [[Official Journal of the European Union]] on the 19th of October. Affected service providers will have until 1 January 2024 to comply with its provisions. Popular online platforms and search engines will need to comply with their obligations four months after they have been designated as such by the EU Commission.<ref name="parl072022" />

== Objectives of the DSA ==
[[Ursula von der Leyen]] proposed a "new Digital Services Act", in her 2019 bid for the European Commission's presidency.<ref>[https://ec.europa.eu/commission/sites/beta-political/files/political-guidelines-next-commission_en.pdf Candidate for President of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen, 'A Union that strives for more: My agenda for Europe' (2019)] (PDF).</ref>
The expressed purpose of the DSA is to update the European Union's legal framework for illegal content on intermediaries, in particular by modernising the [[Electronic Commerce Directive 2000|e-Commerce Directive]] adopted in 2000. In doing so, the DSA aims to harmonise different national laws in the European Union that have emerged at national level to address illegal content.<ref name="euractive20200808">{{Cite web|last=Stolton|first=Samuel|date=2020-08-18|title=Digital agenda: Autumn/Winter Policy Briefing|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/digital/news/digital-agenda-autumn-winter-policy-briefing/|access-date=2020-09-02|website=www.euractiv.com|language=en-GB}}</ref> Most prominent amongst these laws has been the German [[Network Enforcement Act|NetzDG]], and similar laws in Austria ("Kommunikationsplattformen-Gesetz") and France ("[[Hate speech laws in France|Loi Avia]]", declared unconstitutional by the Constitutional Council). With the adoption of the Digital Services Act at European level, those national laws would be overwritten and would have to be repealed.<ref>{{Cite web |title=EUR-Lex - primacy_of_eu_law - EN - EUR-Lex |url=https://eur-lex.europa.eu/EN/legal-content/glossary/primacy-of-eu-law.html |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=eur-lex.europa.eu |language=en}}</ref>

In practice, this will mean new legislation regarding illegal content, transparent advertising and disinformation.<ref name="ft20201028">{{Cite web|last=Espinoza|first=Javier|title=Internal Google document reveals campaign against EU lawmakers|url=https://www.ft.com/content/d9d05b1e-45c0-44b8-a1ba-3aa6d0561bed|date=28 October 2020|website=Financial Times}}</ref>

== Preparatory phase ==
The Digital Services Act builds in large parts on the non-binding Commission Recommendation 2018/314 of 1 March 2018<ref>{{Cite journal |date=2018-03-06 |title=Commission Recommendation (EU) 2018/334 of 1 March 2018 on measures to effectively tackle illegal content online |url=http://data.europa.eu/eli/reco/2018/334/oj/eng |language=en}}</ref> when it comes to illegal content on platforms. However, it goes further in addressing topics such as disinformation and other risks especially on very large online platforms. As part of the preparatory phase, the European Commission launched a public consultation on the package to gather evidence between July and September 2020.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Press corner |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/home/en |access-date=2020-09-02 |website=European Commission - European Commission |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Europe asks for views on platform governance and competition tools |url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2020/06/02/europe-asks-for-views-on-platform-governance-and-competition-tools/ |access-date=2020-09-02 |website=TechCrunch |date=2 June 2020 |language=en-US}}</ref> An impact assessment was published alongside the proposal on 15 December 2020 with the relevant evidence base.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Impact assessment of the Digital Services Act {{!}} Shaping Europe's digital future |url=https://digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu/en/library/impact-assessment-digital-services-act |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=digital-strategy.ec.europa.eu |language=en}}</ref>

== New obligations on platform companies ==

The DSA is meant to improve content moderation on social media platforms to address concerns about illegal content.<ref name=EDRi/> It is organised in five chapters, with the most important Chapters regulating the liability exemption of intermediaries (Chapter 2), the obligations on intermediaries (Chapter 3), and the cooperation and enforcement framework between the commission and national authorities (Chapter 4).

The DSA proposal maintains the current rule according to which companies that host other's data are not liable for the content unless they actually know it is illegal, and upon obtaining such knowledge do not act to remove it.<ref name="EDRi">{{cite web |url= https://edri.org/our-work/eu-attempt-to-regulate-big-tech/| title= The EU's attempt to regulate Big Tech: What it brings and what is missing |publisher= [[European Digital Rights]] (EDRi) | date=December 18, 2020 |access-date=December 29, 2020|archive-url=https://archive.today/20210416193315/https://edri.org/our-work/eu-attempt-to-regulate-big-tech/|archive-date=2021-04-16|url-status=live}}</ref>
This so-called "conditional liability exemption" is fundamentally different<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://www.elgaronline.com/view/9781839104824.xml |title=The Responsibility of Online Intermediaries for Illegal User Content in the EU and the US |date=2020-11-19 |isbn=978-1-83910-483-1 |language=en|last1=Wilman |first1=Folkert }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Johnson |first1=Ashley |last2=Castro |first2=Daniel |date=2021-02-22 |title=How Other Countries Have Dealt With Intermediary Liability |url=https://itif.org/publications/2021/02/22/how-other-countries-have-dealt-intermediary-liability |website=Information Technology and Innovation Foundation |language=en}}</ref> from the broad immunities given to intermediaries under the equivalent rule ("[[Section 230|Section 230 CDA]]") in the United States.

In addition to the liability exemptions, the DSA would introduce a wide-ranging set of new obligations on platforms, including some that aim to disclose to regulators how their algorithms work, while other obligations would create transparency on how decisions to remove content are taken and on the way advertisers target users.

A November 16, 2021 ''Internet Policy Review'' listed some of new obligations including mandatory "notice-and-action" requirements, for example, respect fundamental rights, mandatory redress for content removal decisions, and a comprehensive risk management and audit framework.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Digital Services Act: risk-based regulation of online platforms |url=https://policyreview.info/articles/news/digital-services-act-risk-based-regulation-online-platforms/1606 |access-date=2022-04-10 |date= 16 November 2021 |website=Internet Policy Review}}</ref>

A December 2020 ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' article said that while many of its provisions only apply to platforms which have more than 45 million users in the [[European Union]], the Act could have repercussions beyond Europe. Platforms including [[Facebook]], Google's subsidiary [[YouTube]], [[Twitter]] and [[TikTok]] would meet that threshold and be subjected to the new obligations.<ref name="Perrigo_20201215">{{cite magazine |url= https://time.com/5921760/europe-digital-services-act-big-tech/| title= How the E.U's Sweeping New Regulations Against Big Tech Could Have an Impact Beyond Europe | last= Perrigo | first=Billy |magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date=December 15, 2020 |access-date=December 29, 2020}}</ref> Companies that do not comply with the new obligations risk fines of up to 10% on their annual turnover.<ref name="Perrigo_20201215"/>

== Legislative history ==

The European Parliament appointed Danish Social Democrat [[Christel Schaldemose]] as rapporteur for the Digital Services Act. On 20 January 2022 the Parliament voted to introduce amendments in the DSA for tracking-free advertising and a ban on using a minor's data for targeted ads, as well as a new right for users to seek compensation for damages.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-01-20 |title=Digital Services Act: regulating platforms for a safer online space for users {{!}} News {{!}} European Parliament |url=https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20220114IPR21017/digital-services-act-regulating-platforms-for-a-safer-online-space-for-users |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=www.europarl.europa.eu |language=en}}</ref> In the wake of the [[2021 Facebook leak|Facebook Files revelations]] and a hearing by Facebook Whistleblower [[Frances Haugen]] in the European Parliament,<ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-08-11 |title=Frances Haugen to MEPs: EU digital rules can be a game changer for the world {{!}} News {{!}} European Parliament |url=https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20211107IPR16801/frances-haugen-to-meps-eu-digital-rules-can-be-a-game-changer-for-the-world |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=www.europarl.europa.eu |language=en}}</ref> the European Parliament also strengthened the rules on fighting disinformation and harmful content, as well as tougher auditing requirements.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Facebook whistleblower Frances Haugen speaks to EU parliament |url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2021/11/08/facebook-whistleblower-frances-haugen-european-parliament/ |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=TechCrunch |date=9 November 2021 |language=en-US}}</ref>

The Council of the European Union adopted its position on 25 November 2021.<ref>{{Cite web |title=What is illegal offline should be illegal online: Council agrees position on the Digital Services Act |url=https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2021/11/25/what-is-illegal-offline-should-be-illegal-online-council-agrees-on-position-on-the-digital-services-act/ |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=www.consilium.europa.eu |language=en}}</ref> The most significant changes introduced by the Member States are to entrust the European Commission with the enforcement of the new rules, in the wake of allegations and complaints that the Irish Data Protection Watchdog was not effectively policing the bloc's data protection rules against platform companies.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ireland's privacy watchdog sued over Google adtech inaction |url=https://social.techcrunch.com/2022/03/14/dpc-sued-google-rtb-complaint/ |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=TechCrunch |date=15 March 2022 |language=en-US}}</ref>

The Data Governance Act (DGA) was formally approved by the European Parliament on April 6, 2022.<ref name="EP_20220406">{{Cite web| title = Data governance: Parliament approves new rules boosting intra-EU data sharing {{!}} News {{!}} European Parliament| access-date = 2022-04-29| date = April 6, 2022| url = https://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20220401IPR26534/data-governance-parliament-approves-new-rules-boosting-intra-eu-data-sharing}}</ref> This sets up a legal framework for common data spaces in Europe which will increase data sharing in sectors such as finance, health, and the environment.<ref name="EP_20220406"/><ref name="Daly_20220427">{{Cite web| last1 = Daly| first1 = Sidley Austin LLP-Ken| last2 = Zdzieborska| first2 = Monika| last3 = Shajko| first3 = Fiona| title = EU Data Governance Act - Edging Closer to a European Single Market for Data| work = Lexology| access-date = 2022-04-29| date = 2022-04-27| url = https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=fbdf102f-9450-4614-9baf-1406b13917cd}}</ref>

With Russia using social media platforms to spread misinformation about the [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine]], European policymakers felt a greater sense of urgency to move the legislation forward to ensure that major tech platforms were transparent and properly regulated, according to ''The Washington Post''.<ref name="Zakrzewski_20220422">{{Cite news| issn = 0190-8286| last = Zakrzewski| first = Cat| title = Europe to slap new regulations on Big Tech, beating U.S. to the punch| newspaper = The Washington Post| accessdate = 2022-04-29| date = 2022-04-22| url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/04/22/european-lawmakers-digital-services/}}</ref> On 22 April 2022, the Council of the European Union and the European Parliament reached a deal on the Digital Services Act in Brussels following sixteen hours of negotiations.<ref name="Satariano_20220422">{{Cite news| issn = 0362-4331| last = Satariano| first = Adam| title = E.U. Takes Aim at Social Media's Harms With Landmark New Law| work = The New York Times| access-date = 2022-04-29| date = 2022-04-22| url = https://www.nytimes.com/2022/04/22/technology/european-union-social-media-law.html}}</ref><ref name="EU_PR_20220423">{{cite press release |author=<!--Not stated--> |title=Digital Services Act: Commission welcomes political agreement on rules ensuring a safe and accountable online environment |url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/en/ip_22_2545 |location=Brussels |publisher=[[European Commission]] |agency= |date=23 April 2022 |access-date=23 April 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Foo Yun Chee |date=22 April 2022 |title=EU sets new online rules for Google, Meta to curb illegal content |url=https://www.reuters.com/technology/eu-countries-lawmakers-clinch-deal-new-online-content-rules-2022-04-23/ |work=[[Reuters]] |location= |access-date=23 April 2022}}</ref> According to ''The Washington Post'', the agreement reached in Brussels solidifies the two-bill plan{{emdash}} the Digital Services Act and the Digital Markets Act, a law regulating competition. The latter is aimed at preventing abuse of power against smaller competitors by larger "gatekeepers". The next stage before the bills become law, is the votes from the Parliament and policymakers from EU 27 nations. This is considered to be a formality.<ref name="Zakrzewski_20220422"/>

== Reactions ==
Media reactions to the Digital Services Act have been generally positive. In January 2022, the editorial board of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' stated that the U.S. could learn from these rules,<ref>{{Cite news |title=Opinion {{!}} The U.S. could learn from Europe's online speech rules |language=en-US |newspaper=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/2022/01/29/us-could-learn-europes-online-speech-rules/ |access-date=2022-04-10 |issn=0190-8286}}</ref> while whistleblower Frances Haugen stated that it could set a "gold standard" of regulation worldwide.<ref>{{Cite journal |date=2021-11-08 |title=EU could set 'gold standard' on big tech - Haugen |url=https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2021/1108/1258662-facebook-haugen-eu/ |language=en}}</ref> Tech journalist Casey Newton has argued that the Digital Services Act will shape US tech policy.<ref>{{Cite news |title=European values are starting to define U.S. tech privacy, says journalist |language=en |work=NPR.org |url=https://www.npr.org/2021/12/04/1061539843/european-values-are-starting-to-define-u-s-tech-privacy-says-journalist?t=1649590691926 |access-date=2022-04-10}}</ref> [[Techdirt]] criticized the Digital Services Act, calling it the "EU's technocratic desire to overregulate the internet" that will "cause real problems" and argued that the DSA would stifle innovation.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Masnick |first=Mike |date=2022-05-13 |title=Because Of Course: Rightsholders Pushing To Turn Digital Services Act Into Another Anti-Piracy Tool |url=https://www.techdirt.com/2022/05/13/because-of-course-rightsholders-pushing-to-turn-digital-services-act-into-another-anti-piracy-tool/ |access-date=2022-10-11 |website=Techdirt |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Masnick |first=Mike |date=2022-08-05 |title=EU To Open New Silicon Valley Office To Figure Out Better And Better Ways To Destroy The Internet |url=https://www.techdirt.com/2022/08/05/eu-to-open-new-silicon-valley-office-to-figure-out-better-and-better-ways-to-destroy-the-internet/ |access-date=2022-10-11 |website=Techdirt |language=en-US}}</ref>

Scholars have begun critically examining the Digital Services Act.<ref>{{Cite web |title=DSA Observatory – a hub of expertise on the DSA package. |url=https://dsa-observatory.eu/ |access-date=2022-04-10 |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=DSA in Perspective Seminar Series |url=https://brusselsprivacyhub.eu/events/dsa-in-perspective-seminar-series |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=Brussels Privacy Hub}}</ref> Some academics have expressed concerns that the Digital Services Act might be too rigid and prescribed,<ref>{{Cite web |title=The DSA's Industrial Model for Content Moderation |url=https://verfassungsblog.de/dsa-industrial-model/ |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=Verfassungsblog |language=de-DE}}</ref> excessively focused on individual content decisions or vague risk assessments.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Douek |first=Evelyn |date=2022-01-10 |title=Content Moderation as Administration |url=https://papers.ssrn.com/abstract=4005326 |language=en |location=Rochester, NY|ssrn=4005326 }}</ref>

Civil Society organisations such as [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] have called for stronger privacy protections.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Schmon |first=Christoph |date=2022-01-20 |title=DSA: EU Parliament Vote Ensures a Free Internet, But a Final Regulation Must Add Stronger Privacy Protections |url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2022/01/dsa-eu-parliaments-position-ensures-free-internet-human-rights-safeguards-need-be |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=Electronic Frontier Foundation |language=en}}</ref> [[Human Rights Watch]] has welcomed the transparency and user remedies but called for an end to abusive surveillance and profiling.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-01-07 |title=EU: Put Fundamental Rights at Top of Digital Regulation |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2022/01/07/eu-put-fundamental-rights-top-digital-regulation |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=Human Rights Watch |language=en}}</ref> [[Amnesty International]] has welcomed many aspects of the proposal in terms of fundamental rights balance, but also asked for further restrictions on advertising.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-03-30 |title=Amnesty International Position on the Proposals for a Digital Services Act and a Digital Markets Act |url=https://www.amnesty.eu/news/amnesty-international-position-on-the-proposals-for-a-digital-services-act-and-a-digital-markets-act/ |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=European Institutions Office |language=en-GB}}</ref> Advocacy organisation [[Avaaz]] has compared the Digital Services Act to the Paris Agreement for climate change.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Nicotra |first=Luca |date=2022-02-24 |title=Could the EU be on the cusp of a Paris Agreement For The Internet? |url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/digital/opinion/could-the-eu-be-on-the-cusp-of-a-paris-agreement-for-the-internet/ |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=www.euractiv.com |language=en-GB}}</ref>

Tech companies have repeatedly criticised the heavy burden of the rules and the alleged lack of clarity of the Digital Services Act,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Documents |url=https://doteurope.eu/library/ |access-date=2022-04-10 |language=en-GB}}</ref> and have been accused of lobbying to undermine some of the more far-reaching demands by law-makers, notably on bans for targeted advertising,<ref>{{Cite web |title=How corporate lobbying undermined the EU's push to ban surveillance ads {{!}} Corporate Europe Observatory |url=https://corporateeurope.org/en/2022/01/how-corporate-lobbying-undermined-eus-push-ban-surveillance-ads |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=corporateeurope.org}}</ref> and a high-profile apology from Sundar Pichai to Thierry Breton on leaked plans by Google to lobby against the Digital Services Act.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Espinoza |first=Javier |date=2020-11-13 |title=Google apologises to Thierry Breton over plan to target EU commissioner |work=Financial Times |url=https://www.ft.com/content/5528eab4-ac19-40c0-893a-9b86ccd091f6 |access-date=2022-04-10}}</ref>

A bipartisan group of US senators have called the DSA and DMA discriminatory,  claiming that the legislation  would "[focus on] regulations on a handful of American companies while failing to regulate similar companies based in Europe, China, Russia and elsewhere."<ref>{{Cite web |title=Finance Committee Leaders Wyden and Crapo: Biden Administration Must Fight Back Against Discriminatory Digital Trade Policies {{!}} The United States Senate Committee on Finance |url=https://www.finance.senate.gov/chairmans-news/finance-committee-leaders-wyden-and-crapo-biden-administration-must-fight-back-against-discriminatory-digital-trade-policies |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=www.finance.senate.gov |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Lawmakers Argue Pending European Tech Laws Disadvantage American Firms |url=https://www.nextgov.com/policy/2022/02/lawmakers-argue-pending-european-tech-laws-disadvantage-american-firms/361480/ |access-date=2022-04-10 |website=Nextgov.com |language=en}}</ref>

The DSA was mostly welcomed by the European media sector.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Bertuzzi|first=Luca|date=2021-06-25|title=Digital Brief: Calls for biometrical ban, online marketplaces' threat, Germany's antitrust crusade|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/digital/news/digital-brief-calls-for-biometrical-ban-online-marketplaces-threat-germanys-antitrust-crusade/|access-date=2021-06-29|website=www.euractiv.com|language=en-GB}}</ref> Due to the influence gatekeepers have in selecting and controlling the visibility of certain journalistic articles over others through their online platforms, the [[European Federation of Journalists]] encouraged EU legislators to further increase the transparency of platforms' recommendation systems via the DSA.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Killeen|first=Molly|date=2021-06-25|title=Media sector eyes opportunity to rebalance relations with online platforms|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/digital/news/media-sector-eyes-opportunity-to-rebalance-relations-with-online-platforms/|access-date=2021-06-29|website=www.euractiv.com|language=en-GB}}</ref>

Nevertheless, the DSA's later stage inter-institutional negotiations, or [[Formal trilogue meeting|Trilogues]], have been criticized as lacking transparency and equitable participation.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Allen |first=Asha |date=April 29, 2022 |title=The EU's Opaque Policy-Making Has Never Been Clearer |magazine=WIRED |url=https://www.wired.com/story/eu-opaque-policy-making-dsa/ |access-date=May 3, 2022}}</ref> These criticisms mirror past experiences with the drafting of the EU Regulation on Preventing the Dissemination of Terrorist Content Online as well as the [[General Data Protection Regulation]] (GDPR).

Swedish MEP [[Jessica Stegrud]] argued that the DSA's focus on preventing the spread of disinformation and "harmful content" would undermine [[freedom of speech]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Stegrud |first=Jessica |date=2022-04-25 |title=The EU's Digital Services Act is undermining free speech, Brussels Report |url=https://www.brusselsreport.eu/2022/04/25/the-eus-digital-services-act-is-undermining-free-speech/ |access-date=2022-10-11 |website=Brussels Report |language=en-US}}</ref>
